title: The Impact of New Public Management Policies and Perspectives on Professional Social Work: a comparison of British and Japanese experiences.
abstractText:
This seminar series will explore the impact of managerialist ideas, policies and practices on one branch of social care provision - professional social work - in the United Kingdom and in Japan.A growing literature suggests that there are also many similarities in the experience of  social workers in different countries, as well as shared concerns about the impact of neoliberalism and managerialism on professional social work practice. These concerns relate to the erosion of the professional value base, the growth of deprofessionalisation, the undermining of the worker/client relationship, the excessive dominance of IT systems, the reduction of a rich interventive repertoire to a reliance of a very narrow range of methods, and the shrinking of worker autonomy and discretion.

The seminar series would explore these issues and concerns through a comparison of the experience of professional social work in Britain and Japan, and specifically would seek to address the following questions:

  • In what ways and to what extent have the dominant managerial policies of the past two decades transformed professional social work practice in Britain and Japan?
  • How has the profession responded to these changes, and what possibilities exist for the emergence of new and different forms of social work practice rooted in concepts of social justice?
